doc_description: This document is a legal memorandum and order from the United States District Court for the District of Massachusetts regarding cross-motions for summary judgment and a motion for leave to file a third-party complaint in a case involving MSP Recovery Claims, Series LLC, and Massachusetts Bay Insurance Company, among others. The case concerns reimbursement of medical expenses under the Medicare Secondary Payer Act.

structure.title: Introduction
structure.summary: The document introduces a legal dispute over reimbursement of medical expenses under the Medicare Secondary Payer Act. MSP Recovery Claims, Series LLC, as the assignee of Blue Cross Blue Shield of Massachusetts, is the plaintiff, while Massachusetts Bay Insurance Company and Citizens Insurance Company of America are the defendants.
structure.text: This is a dispute concerning reimbursement of certain medical expenses pursuant to the Medicare Secondary Payer Act of 1980, 42 U.S.C. § 1395y(b) et seq. (“MSP Act”). Plaintiff MSP Recovery Claims, Series LLC (“MSPRC”) is the assignee of Blue Cross Blue Shield of Massachusetts (“BCBSMA”), a health insurer. Defendants Massachusetts Bay Insurance Company (“Massachusetts Bay”) and Citizens Insurance Company of America (“Citizens”) are property and casualty insurers that sell, among other products, automobile insurance.

structure.title: Background
structure.summary: The background section outlines the parties involved, the statutory framework of the MSP Act, and the factual background of the claims. It details the assignment of claims from BCBSMA to MSP Recovery Claims and the specific claims involving A.D. and P.R.
structure.text: The following facts are undisputed unless otherwise noted. MSPRC is a Delaware series limited liability company. It is the assignee of Blue Cross Blue Shield of Massachusetts (“BCBSMA”) as to the claims asserted in this lawsuit. BCBSMA is a Massachusetts health insurer and a Medicare Advantage Organization (“MAO”).

structure.title: Cross-Motions for Summary Judgment
structure.summary: This section discusses the legal standard for summary judgment and analyzes the cross-motions for summary judgment filed by the parties. It addresses the MSP-Act claims against Massachusetts Bay and Citizens, as well as the breach-of-contract claim against Massachusetts Bay.
structure.text: The role of summary judgment is “to pierce the pleadings and to assess the proof in order to see whether there is a genuine need for trial.” Summary judgment shall be granted when “there is no genuine dispute as to any material fact and the movant is entitled to judgment as a matter of law.”

structure.title: Motion for Leave to File Third-Party Complaint
structure.summary: Citizens Insurance Company of America filed a motion for leave to file a third-party complaint seeking indemnification from P.R. The court denies the motion, citing the late stage of litigation and minimal prejudice to Citizens.
structure.text: Citizens has moved for leave to file a third-party complaint seeking indemnification from P.R. pursuant to its settlement agreement. Given the late stage of the litigation—the claims currently before the Court will be resolved upon issuance of this order—and the minimal resulting prejudice that Citizens might suffer in being required to pursue indemnification in a separate action, the motion will be denied.

structure.title: Conclusion
structure.summary: The court grants summary judgment in favor of the defendants on Counts 1 and 2, and in favor of the plaintiff on Count 3. The motion for leave to file a third-party complaint is denied. Damages are awarded to the plaintiff on Count 3.
structure.text: For the foregoing reasons, plaintiff’s motion for summary judgment is DENIED as to Count 1 and GRANTED as to Count 3; defendants’ motion for summary judgment is GRANTED as to Counts 1 and 2, and DENIED as to Count 3; and defendant Citizens Insurance Company of America’s motion for leave to file a third-party complaint is DENIED. Damages are hereby awarded to plaintiff on Count 3 in the amount of $38,846.90.
